Doctors strike: After hours of wait, pat.description: HYDERABAD: Hundreds of patients who visited government-run tertiary centres such as Gandhi Hospital, Osmania General Hospital (OGH), Nizams Institute of Medical Sciences (NIMS), Niloufer Hospital and Government ENT Hospital, were denied treatment as out-patient services remained completely shut. While emergency services continued at all hospitals, there were delays, queues and chaos everywhere because of staff shortage. Private facilities, too, largely remained out of bounds (except for emergency services). As a result, hundreds of patients had to return without treatment. While many others stood in queues for hours together, patients with medical emergency, too, had to wait for one to two hours amid the chaos. Sanjeev Singh Yadav, state secretary of Indian Medical Association, said, “Participation from private and corporate sector hospitals in the strike, including small-time clinics, was almost absolute on Monday.” In addition to strike over assaults on doctors, junior doctors are protesting against the state government’s decision to increase retirement age of faculty. At many places, there were delays in arranging stretchers and taking patients inside the hospitals. Among them was 40-year-old Mahender, a paralysis patient who was made to wait at the entrance of Gandhi Hospital in the out-patient ward for almost an hour as there wasn’t enough staff or doctors to attend to him. The patient, a migrant worker from Nalgonda, was seen lying helpless in the hospital premises till the staff arrived an hour later. There were others who had already been turned away by one or two other hospitals. A paralysis patient, Mallesh K, who was turned away from the area hospital in Malakpet and government Unani hospital at Charminar, reached OGH on Monday morning complaining of giddiness and extreme discomfort. Suresh K, who accompanied his mother, and father Mallesh from Nalgonda, said: “We came to Hyderabad three days ago and after visiting two hospitals, we were redirected here. We have been going from room-to-room from morning, but there is no clarity on what to do. My father cannot be admitted as there are no doctors.” Patients who had travelled to the city from far off locations such as Mahbubnagar, Nalgonda, Warangal and other states, too, were left in the lurch as they were unaware of the strike and had already been given Monday’s date for consultation. Several patients and their attendants were seen crying as they went without food or water in the queues. At several places in the hospitals, volunteers of Helping Hand Foundation were seen outside OPDs, counselling patients and their attendants to come back on Tuesday for consultation. Cabinet nod for secretariat building.description: HYDERABAD: The Telangana state cabinet on Tuesday approved the proposals for construction of a new secretariat and legislative assembly, which will be on the lines of parliament building, at a cost of Rs 500 crore. A three-member cabinet sub-committee headed by roads and buildings minister Vemula Prashanth Reddy has been appointed will fine-tune the modalities. The cabinet also gave powers to chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao to take a final call on the construction of the new secretariat and assembly. “While the new secretariat will be built at the existing secretariat complex at a cost of Rs 400 crore with around six lakh square ft built-up area, the new assembly will be constructed at Irrum Manzil in 17 acres, which is set to cost Rs 100 crore. Foundation stone for the new secretariat will be laid on June 27,” chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao told mediapersos after the cabinet meeting. The chief minister said the new assembly would resemble parliament with a central hall, council hall and other facilities and the front elevation of the assembly would look like the front elevation of the present assembly building. He also said since the present assembly building is a heritage structure, it would not be demolished. “We will try to utilise the building for relocating other departments,” he said. “The Andhra Pradesh government is likely to hand over the secretariat block under its control to us either on June 19 or 20. Shifting of secretariat departments will be taken soon,” the CM said. He said the designs for the new secretariat have not been finalised yet. “We are still looking at various designs from different parts of the country,” he said. The cabinet also discussed on maintaining harmonious relations with neighbouring states of Andhra Pradesh, Karnataka and Maharashtra. The CM said Maharashtra supported Telangana in getting clearances for Kaleshwaram project, while Karnataka had released water to Krishna basin in Mahbubnagar district. He said issues over sharing of water with AP would also be discussed threadbare. “Both the Telugu states have Godavari and Krishna waters allocation of 1.480 tmcft and 811 tmcft respectively. If both assured and flood waters is taken into consideration, the water quantity will touch 5,000 tmcft which needs to be utilised effectively by both the states. A team of irrigation officials from AP are coming to Hyderabad to discuss the issues either on June 27 or 28 and joint spot inspection will also be carried out to resolve the pending issues between the states pertaining to irrigation,” he said. The chief minister said the cabinet discussed about the pay revision commission and enhancing the retirement age to government employees. “We want to announce PRC and retirement issue as a package by taking the state finances into consideration,” he said. Shiv Sena List 2019.description: MUMBAI: Shiv Sena has come up with it's first list of 21 candidates, out of 23 to contest in Lok Sabha polls in Maharashtra. Except Osmanabad, 17 sitting Sena MP's are part of the list, includes Mumbai, Thane, Kalyan, Raigad. Following complaints received by local functionaries from Osmanabad, the party has denied ticket to sitting MP Ravindra Gaikwad. Gaikwad, who had allegedly hit an Air India staffer with his slipper because he was refused a business class seat in March 2017. Maharashtra: Track here Lok Sabha elections' full coverageSena has kept two seats, Palghar and Satara, on hold, likely to announce on Sunday. Late Chintaman Wanga, former BJP MP's son Shrinivas likely to contest from Palghar on Sena ticket whereas former NCP legislator Narendra Patil may might contest as Sena candidate from Satara. Patil met Shiv Sena president Uddhav Thackeray on Friday at Matoshree. Other candidates are: South Mumbai: Arvind Sawant; South Central Mumbai: Rahul Shewale; Mumbai North West: Gajanan Kirtikar; Kalyan: Shrikant Shinde; Raigad: union minister Anant Gite; Osmanabad: Omraje Nimbalkar, Ratnagiri-Sindhudurg: Vinayak Raut; Kolhapur-Sanjay Mandlik; Hatkanangle: Dhairyasheel Mane; Nashik: Hemant Godse; Shirdi: Sadashiv Lokhande; Shirur: Shivajirao Adhalrao Patil; Aurangabad: Chandrakant Khaire; Yavatmal Washim: Bhawana Gawli; Buldana: Prataprao Jadhav; Ramtek: Kripal Tumane; Amrawati-Anandrao Adsul, Parbhani: Sanjay Jadhav; Maval: Shrirang Barne; Hingoli: Hemant Patil. \nA fairy tale reception for cricketer T.description: Amidst a magnificently illumined golden setting, stood the bride in gold, holding her prince charming. This fairy tale wedding reception of cricketer T Suman with his lady love Julaiikha, was a grand affair attended by city cricketers and celebs. In a huge screen beside the stage, a five minute video, rewinding moments from their wedding ceremony was also being relayed.  Amidst the celebrations, Charan, the bride’s brother, staged a flashmob surprise for the bride and groom. Out of the blue, a group of 14 started dancing on popular chartbusters like Kala Chasma, Sheela ki jawani and legendary hits of Michael Jackson to celebrate the wedding ceremony. Though astounded initially, it soon brought smiles to Suman and Julaiikha’s faces. The celebration went on till wee hours, where the guests bonded over delicious food and good music. Habsiguda residents seek school\u2019s c.description: Hyderabad: Residents of a street in Habsiguda are up in arms against a corporate group, demanding that a school set up by the group be closed immediately. The residents have been staging protests for 13 days. They said the presence of multiple schools in the locality was leading to traffic jams. “There are at least 10 apartments and individual houses in the lane where the school was set up. Despite several residents protesting against the opening of the school, the management went ahead and admitted students,” said A Nanda Kumar, a protestor. Another resident AM Reddy said navigating through the narrow 25ft road has become a nightmare. “With the presence of several schools — some with more than 500 students — living here has become a mess,” he said. Some residents said that there was hardly any space for a fire engine to enter the locality. tnn Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .
